question: A 2 kg ball is moving to the right with a speed of 4 m/s when it is struck by a bat, reversing its direction and increasing its speed to 6 m/s. What is the impulse delivered by the bat to the ball?
solution: Impulse equals the change in momentum: J = Δp. The initial momentum is p_i = mv_i = (2 kg)(4 m/s) = 8 kg·m/s to the right. The final momentum is p_f = mv_f = (2 kg)(-6 m/s) = -12 kg·m/s (to the left). So, Δp = p_f - p_i = (-12 kg·m/s) - (8 kg·m/s) = -20 kg·m/s. The negative sign indicates the impulse is to the left. Converting to N·s (1 kg·m/s = 1 N·s), the impulse delivered by the bat is 20 N·s to the left.
